references: Verner, J. and A. Boss. 1980. California wildlife and their habitats: western Sierra Nevada. For. Serv. Gen. Tech. Rep. PSW37. U.S. Dep. Agric. Berkeley, CA.
Hall, Raymond E. 1946. Mammals of Nevada University of California Press, Berkely and Los Angeles, California.
Verts, B.J., and L.N. Carraway. 2001. Scapanus latimanus. Mammalian Species 666: 1-7.

Yates, T. L. 1999. Broad-footed mole: Scapanus latimanus. Pages 57-58 in Wilson, D. E. and S. Ruff, editors. The Smithsonian book of North American mammals. Smithsonian Institute Press, Washington and London. 750pp.
habitat_description:
Southwest/Northwest:
“… occurs in moist, fairly rich soils with scant vegetation.”   “… rarely occur in heavy clay, gravelly, or stony soils.”  “Rocky areas and bodies of water likely are barriers to distribution of the species…”  “Sandy and other loose soils usually are not occupied..”  (Verts and Carroway 2001).  “… cannot dig effectively in dry, baked soils, although certain soils which fail to attract moles in the dry season support them in a wet season.” Along the East Walker River in July, “moles were confined to the moist soil along the river bank, but in the preceding spring they had worked several yards back from the river.”  (Hall 1946).  “...common in most of California except the hot deserts and portions of the Central Valley. Optimal habitats are annual and perennial grassland, pasture, montane and valley foothill riparian, and aspen. Also occurs in cropland, orchard-vineyard, wet meadow, and a variety of open forest habitats” (California Wildlife Habitat Relationship System 2003). In Oregon, an individual was collected in shrub-steppe (with big sagebrush [Artemisia tridentata] (Verts and Carroway 2001). In the Sierra Nevada of California, “favors moist areas, especially nears streams, bogs, and meadows.”  “Special habitat requirements: “moist areas with friable soils for burrowing; forest openings.” (Verner and Boss 1980).  Elevation range is 0 - 3000m (Verts and Carroway 2001). In California, this species can be found in grasslands, pasture, montane and valley foothill, riparian forests as well as aspen woodland and open forests. Elevation range is up to 3000m in Sierra Nevadas (Yates 1999). The broad-footed mole prefers moist, friable soils for burrowing and tunneling.
